unnormalised: I've been thinking a lot about titles lately, especially in the medical field. My grandfather, Hari Sharma, was a compounder (basically a pharmacist's assistant) back in the 60s in a small village in UP. Everyone just called him "Sharmaji". No formal “Mr.”, no “Bhai,” just Sharmaji. He knew all the local remedies and was the first point of contact for most villagers before they considered going to a proper doctor in the city 50 km away.
normalised: I've been thinking a lot about titles lately, especially in the medical field. No formal “mister”, no “Bhai,” just Sharmaji. He knew all the local remedies and was the first point of contact for most villagers before they considered going to a proper doctor in the city fifty kilometer away.

unnormalised: Then there’s my cousin, Priya. After years of grueling study, she's finally Dr. Priya Sharma, MD. It’s surreal to think about the journey she took, from prepping for NEET at Allen coaching classes in Kota to finally holding that degree. The respect she commands now is palpable. People address her with utmost deference, always “Dr. Sharma,” even outside the hospital. It's a world away from Sharmaji, isn't it? The weight of those initials, “MD,” is heavy with expectations, responsibilities, and, of course, prestige.

The weight of those initials, “M-D,” is heavy with expectations, responsibilities, and, of course, prestige.

unnormalised: But it got me wondering about all the other titles and roles within the medical hierarchy. You've got the RN, registered nurses, who are often the unsung heroes of patient care. They're the ones spending the most time at the bedside, administering meds and monitoring vitals, and yet they often don't get the same recognition as the physicians. My aunt, for instance, worked as a nurse for over 30 years in a govt. hospital in Kerala. She always felt that “Nurse” was enough, not needing further qualification. Still, it felt a bit…diminishing.

unnormalised: Then there's the MBBS, the Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery. It’s like the entry point for becoming a doctor in India, right? But even after that, you have specializations. You might have Dr. Patel, a Cardiologist, or Dr. Khan, a neurosurgeon. The specialization title adds another layer of understanding to their expertise. You also have the paramedical staff – technicians, therapists, assistants. They all have specific titles depending on their roles and qualifications - Radiographer, Physiotherapist, Lab Technician, etc. The level of training varies significantly, of course, but each title implies a distinct skillset and responsibility.

unnormalised: And what about the honorifics? I've heard older patients address doctors as "Vaidya ji" still, a nod to the traditional Ayurvedic practitioners. I’ve even heard “Hakim Saab” in some parts of Old Delhi. Does that mean the formal “Dr.” title is losing its cultural significance? Or are these just remnants of a different time? Maybe it's just a cultural thing that's specific to certain areas. I recall my grandmother saying that "Vaidya" was a term of respect for someone who knew about healing.

unnormalised: The thing is, titles aren't just about hierarchy or formality. They're about communication. When I see “Dr.”, I immediately understand that this person has undergone extensive medical training and is qualified to diagnose and treat illnesses. When I hear “Nurse,” I know I'm talking to someone who is skilled in patient care. These titles give us quick, shorthand ways to understand each other’s roles and responsibilities. So is the title that important after all?

unnormalised: Ultimately, it’s the competence and compassion behind the title that truly matters. Whether it's Dr. Sharma with her shiny new MD or Sharmaji with his decades of experience and local knowledge, the real value lies in their ability to heal and care for others. And perhaps, someday, there will be a greater appreciation for all the roles, big and small, within the healthcare system and the importance of the contribution that each one makes to a patient's wellbeing.
